params.text: Electric safety with a Benchtop Power Supply (Aim-TTi  EX354RT)

A power supply is an electrical device that supplies electric power to an electrical load. The main purpose of a power supply is to convert electric current from a source to the correct voltage, current, and frequency to power the load.

It is one of the most important tools of an electronic engineer, and today we will look at the the commom safety and control features of a benchtop power supply.

To pass the course you must answer every question and click "Submit report" on the last page.

metadata.title: Electric safety with a Benchtop Power Supply (Aim-TTi  EX354RT)

params.text: Safety rules

Use of this instrument in a manner not specified by these instructions may impair the safety protection provided. Do not operate the instrument outside its rated supply voltages or environmental range.

This instrument has been designed for indoor use in a Pollution Degree 2 environment in the temperature range 5°C to 40°C, 20% - 80% RH (non-condensing). It may occasionally be subjected to temperatures between +5°C and –10°C without degradation of its safety. Do not operate while condensation is present.

[EDITOR]: It should be okay as long as it is in a lab with the windows closed

If the instrument is clearly defective, has been subject to mechanical damage, excessive moisture or chemical corrosion the safety protection may be impaired and the apparatus should be withdrawn from use and returned for checking and repair.

[EDITOR]: If a defect or a malfunction is spotted, disconect the instrument from power, remove it from use and consult with the responsible person.

When the instrument is connected to its supply, terminals may be live and opening the covers or removal of parts (except those to which access can be gained by hand) is likely to expose live parts. The apparatus shall be disconnected from all voltage sources before it is opened for any adjustment, replacement, maintenance or repair. Capacitors inside the power supply may still be charged even if the power supply has been disconnected from all voltage sources but will be safely discharged about 10 minutes after switching off power.

Any adjustment, maintenance and repair of the opened instrument under voltage shall be avoided as far as possible and, if inevitable, shall be carried out only by a skilled person who is aware of the hazard involved.

Make sure that only fuses with the required rated current and of the specified type are used for replacement. The use of makeshift fuses and the short-circuiting of fuse holders is prohibited.

[EDITOR]: Students in HSHL are prohibited from opening, making changes or improvements to the school`s tools and devices. If maintanence is needed, consult with the person responsible and remove the instrument from the work area in case of malfunction. 

Do not wet the instrument or use solvents when cleaning it.

Mains Operating Voltage
This instrument has a universal input range and will operate from a nominal 115V or 230V mains supply without adjustment. Check that the local supply meets the AC Input requirement given in the Specification.

WARNING! THIS INSTRUMENT MUST BE EARTHED

Any interruption of the mains earth conductor inside or outside the instrument will make the instrument dangerous. Intentional interruption is prohibited. The protective action must not be negated by the use of an extension cord without a protective conductor.

Top three pictrures: earthed plug and sockets
Bottom two: unearthed cable for comparison

A fault or accidental damage may cause live conductors to come into contact with the metal casing of apparatus or other accessible metal parts of an installation.

It is, therefore, necessary to ensure that should this happen the fault current does not flow for long enough to cause damage or fire, and that there is no risk of anybody receiving a shock should they be touching the metalwork. This is achieved by connecting any such metal work to the general mass of earth, so that the resistance of the path to earth is low enough to ensure that sufficient fault current passes to operate the protective device and also that the fault current takes this earth path rather than through a person touching the metalwork

Mains Lead

Connect the instrument to the AC supply using the mains lead provided. Should a mains plug be required for a different mains outlet socket, a suitably rated and approved mains lead set should be used which is fitted with the required wall plug and an IEC60320 C13 connector for the instrument end. To determine the minimum current rating of the lead-set for the intended AC supply, refer to the power rating information on the equipment or in the Specification.

Ventilation

The power supply is very efficient but nevertheless can generate significant heat at full power. The supply relies on convection cooling only and it is therefore important that ventilation is never restricted if performance and safety are to be maintained
General operation
Connection to the Load The load should be connected to the positive (red) and negative (black) output terminals. Both are fully floating and either can be connected to ground

A floating ground is a reference point for electrical potential in a circuit which is galvanically isolated from actual earth ground.

Most electrical circuits have a ground which is electrically connected to the Earth, hence the name "ground". The ground is said to be floating when this connection does not exist.

Precautions

  • Be aware of the isolation voltage limits of your power supply. Do not connect the floating output to voltages beyond its insulation rating.
  • Understand your circuit's grounding scheme to avoid accidental shorts when using floating supplies.

Floating outputs allow you to:

  • Use the supply in positive or negative configurations.
  • Combine multiple supplies for higher voltages (e.g., two 10V supplies in series for 20V).
  • Implement split rails (e.g., ±12V from two supplies).

Series or Parallel Connection with Other Outputs 

The outputs of the power supply are fully floating and may be used in series with other power supply units to generate high DC voltages up to 300V DC.

The maximum permissible voltage between any terminal and earth ground is 300VDC; the maximum permissible voltage between either terminal of one output and any terminal of another output on the same supply is also 300VDC.

WARNING! Such voltages are exceedingly hazardous and great care should be taken to shield the output terminals for such use. On no account should the output terminals be touched when the unit is switched on under such use. All connections to the terminals must be made with the power switched off on all units.

It should be noted that the unit can only source current and cannot sink it, thus units cannot be series connected in anti-phase.

The unit can be connected in parallel with others to produce higher currents. Where several units are connected in parallel, the output voltage will be equal to that of the unit with the highest output voltage setting until the current drawn exceeds its current limit setting, upon which the output will fall to that of the next highest setting, and so on.

In constant current mode, units can be connected in parallel to provide a current equal to the sum of the current limit settings.
Voltage and current control
Voltage and current control in a benchtop power supply are fundamental for safely and effectively powering electronic circuits. Here’s an explanation of how these controls work

1. Voltage Control

Purpose: Allows you to set the desired voltage that the power supply will output to the connected load.

How It Works:

  • Voltage Regulation:

    • The power supply uses an internal feedback mechanism to maintain the set voltage regardless of changes in the load (as long as the current demand is within limits).
    • The circuit continuously compares the output voltage to the desired voltage and adjusts the power conversion system to match the target value.

  • User Interface:

    • A voltage knob (or digital input) allows you to set the output voltage.
    • The display shows the current output voltage.
Example:

If you set the voltage to 5V, the power supply will adjust its internal circuits to ensure that the output remains at 5V, even if the connected device changes its resistance slightly.

2. Current Control

Purpose: Allows you to limit the maximum current the power supply can deliver to the load.

How It Works:

  • Current Limiting:

    • The power supply monitors the current flowing through the load.
    • If the current reaches the set limit, the supply adjusts the output voltage downward to keep the current at or below the limit.
    • This is known as constant current mode (as opposed to constant voltage mode).

  • User Interface:

    • A current knob (or digital input) lets you set the maximum allowable current.
    • The display shows the actual current flowing to the load.

Example:

If you set a current limit of 1A, the power supply ensures that the current never exceeds this value. If the load tries to draw more, the voltage will drop to maintain the current at 1A.

Below you will find a series of examples, showcasing the automatic switching between the modes, using a light bulb rated 15 V on 0.200 A:

items.description: First, lets show what will happen if we will set up power supply according to the rating.

Observe, that we are in current control, as indicated by the Red diode on the instriment.
The supply right now measures the current going through the load and limits the voltage so that the current never exceeds the inputed value and the lightbulb glows as brightly as it is safe.
Let us see what will happen if we put the voltage way below the rating and keep the current the same

The instrument is in voltage control, limiting the current to match the voltage as per Ohms Law.
the light bulb glows dimmly.
to once again show the current control feature, let us crank the voltage way up.
As expected, the current control took over, limiting the voltage to the safe values. The light bulb glows as bright as safety allows it.
as the last experiment let us turn in on with the current value below the rating, while the Voltage is equal to it

as expected, we are in current control, limiting voltage to agree with the chosen current value.

The light bulb is slightly dim.

params.text:
Postscript

Please note that these operating instructions are only intended as a guide and cannot cover all specific aspects of your individual charging station. IT IS IMPORTANT that you familiarize yourself with the operating instructions before using the tool. and, if necessary, follow the manufacturer's specific safety requirements. You should also familiarize yourself with the local laws and regulations relating to the operation and safety of charging station, electrical tools and batteries.

Remember, that in HSHL students take are obliged to:

  • Take responsibility for own safety and health
  • Take responsibility for the safety and health of those higher education institution members who are affected by own actions

We highly recommend you familiarize yourself with any electrical or potentially harmful appliance by either looking at the manual or seeking instructions from someone more experienced with the equipment. This will help you avoid needless headaches and / or getting hurt.

(Thank you for sticking with us through the safety section and making sure the labs stay safe and welcoming.)
